Award.AbstractNarration:
Einstein's theory of General Relativity is known to break down (become singular) when gravitational fields become sufficiently strong. The Big Bang is an example. A similar breakdown in electromagnetism on the atomic scale is cured by switching to a theory that obeys the principles of quantum mechanics. It is hoped that a quantum theory of gravity will remove the singularities in General Relativity. The research performed under this award aims to provide new insights and discover novel directions to answer fundamental questions on the removal (or resolution) of these singularities. Quantum gravitational effects will be systematically taken into account to understand the way singularities in cosmological and black hole spacetimes are resolved. By building on quantum cosmology (the quantization of simple model universes), investigations on more complex models will be performed with the goal of yielding insights on the generic resolution of singularities in quantum gravity. Phenomenological models will be built to understand broad ramifications of the quantum gravity effects in the cosmological scenarios. Another goal of the research will to be address related foundational issues in quantum cosmology, such as a consistent way to assign probabilities for events in a quantum universe.

This research will lead to deeper understanding of the new physics at the quantum gravity (Planck) scale that will have broad implications for quantum gravity, cosmology and other areas of physics. The research on singularity resolution in different models will provide useful hints on the full theory of quantum gravity. This NSF award will also lead to a training of a graduate student leading to a long term impact on his/her research career. Results obtained in this award will be disseminated to the scientific community by writing scholarly articles and seminars in conferences and workshops. The fundamental questions addressed in this award also have broad interest of the general public. Results will be disseminated to the public in various ways including contributions to the loop quantum gravity website.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Einstein's theory of general relativity is extremely successful in describing the dynamics of our universe when gravity is weak. However, it fails to answer fundamental questions about the very first moments of the birth of our universe.  According to general relativity, evolution of our universe backwards in time results in an event called the big bang where the gravitational field becomes infinite. Such events are called  singularities where all known laws of physics break down. It has been widely believed that singularities arise due to assuming that the notion of continuous spacetime is valid at the scales even very close to the singularities. However, at very small scales  quantum effects, which are essential to describe the physics at the microspic scales, are expected to play an important role. The key question is whether incorporating quantum effects in gravity results in insights on these fundamental issues. This NSF project aimed at understanding the union of gravity and the quantum to explain the resolution of singularities.

To achieve the research goals of this project, investigations of modifications to Einstein's equations were studied by developing models of various physically interesting spacetimes. These included spacetimes which
describe our cosmological universes as well as the black holes. It turns out that the quantum modifications change the structure of the classical spacetime in a profound way. Unlike the classical spacetime which
is perceived to be continuous, the quantum spacetime comes with a  discrete structure. When the gravitational field is weak, the discrete quantum spacetime can be approximated by the continuum classical spacetime, and the Einstein's theory is recovered. Investigation of physics of the quantum spacetime introduces various conceptual and  technical challenges. New techniques -- mathematical as well as computational, are required to extract the physics of these spacetimes. In the project, various novel techniques were developed and simulations of the model universes were performed using high performance computational methods. Rigorous analysis of various spacetimes revealed that thanks to the quantum gravitational effects, the big bang singularity is resolved and replaced by a bounce. The universe does not originate from the big bang, but had a life before the big bang in a contracting branch which is smoothly joined with our expanding branch of the universe via a quantum gravitational bridge. Quantum effects were found to play an important role in the resolution of singularities which is found to be a generic feature of quantum spacetimes in the research carried out in this project. In addition to the development of various analytical and numerical tools and probing answers to the questions related to the big bang in different spacetimes, this project also addressed fundamental questions about the way probabilities about quantum events can be assigned to the universe as a whole. It turns out that consistent probabilities for the singularities to occur in quantum gravitational spacetimes turn out to be zero.
